abstract.text: A node that lights surrounding nodes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: To use lighting, add a light node to the scene. Because lights are nodes, they can be moved or perform actions just like other nodes. However, light nodes are invisible except through their effects on sprite nodes configured to interact with them. When a sprite node is affected by a light, the lighting properties of the light node and the lighting properties of the sprite node determine what is rendered. Lighting may affect how unrelated portions of the scene are rendered. For example, if a sprite is configured to cast a shadow, the shadow is rendered on top of other content.
object add lighting to the scene if all of the following  are true:
The light node and the sprite node are both in the scene.
property and one of the sprite’s lighting masks are logically combined using an AND operation, and the result is a nonzero number.
describes the different kinds of effects that can be generated by a light, based on which mask is being tested on the sprite.
The sprite is lit by the light with specular, diffuse, and ambient lighting.
When the light casts a ray that intersects the sprite, a shadow is projected past the sprite, rendered on top of any content that is below the sprite.
If the sprite is inside a shadow cast by a light and the sprite has a lower z position than the light, the shadow affects how the sprite is lit.
If any of the criteria are not met, the sprite is considered unlit and is rendered using the default behavior.

abstract.text: A true value.
Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
A node that plays audio.
A node that applies physics effects to nearby nodes.
A node that lights surrounding nodes.
The ambient color of the light.
A mask that defines which categories this light belongs to.
The exponent for the rate of decay of the light source.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the node is casting light.
The diffuse and specular color of the light source.
The color of any shadow cast by a sprite.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
An image or solid color.
Add lighting and shadows to your scene with light nodes.

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
